ygData.subject: Suggestion For 1st Order Concept Held Inviolate In Genome (Direct/Indirect)
ygData.msgSnippet: A suggestion for a generic 1st order concept , to be held inviolate withing the genome (direct or indirect encoding): Linear Regression/Classification (LRC)

A suggestion for a generic 1st order "concept", to be held inviolate within=
g the genome (direct or indirect encoding):
Linear Regression/Classificatio=
n (LRC) hypothesis model, based upon the following:
1) Model selection of i=
ncluded polynomial terms based upon minimization of delta error between tra=
ining and cross-validation errors,
2) LRC embedded within single multi-inpu=
t/output node of start genome,
3) Start genome configured w/ LRC embedded n=
ode with input weights of 1.0 to each corresponding input of genome,
4) Sta=
rt genome configured w/ LRC embedded node with scaled output w/ weights of =
1.0 to each corresponding output of genome,
5) Start genome configured w/ L=
RC embedded node with scaled outputs for each polynomial term within the LR=
C model, yet not connected,
6) LRC interior functionality held inviolate wi=
thin genome,
The resulting start genome should have the following character=
istics:
a) Start performance equivalent to LRC,
b) LRC interior complexity =
does not contribute to dimensional operator disruption,
c) All significant =
LRC interior non-linear terms are available for additional complexification=
 if justifiable,
The rational for this suggestion as follows:
i. Computatio=
nal overhead for development of the LRC is expended once,
ii. Computational=
 overhead for LRC hypothesis model selection is low,
iii. Computational pro=
cess for development of the LRC is well understood,
iv. There is no good re=
ason to re-invent the wheel, corresponding to the cost of evolving rudiment=
ary performance equivalent of the LRC in NN formative elements,
v. LRC inte=
rior non-linear terms are available for complexification, and therefore do =
not require evolutionary development from NN formative elements,
vi. The ge=
neral truism, that it is usually easier/faster/quicker to modify and improv=
e something that is in-the-ballpark, than start from scratch.

Andy
